title-group.article-title: Three-dimensional analysis of micro-residual stresses in fibrous composites based on the energy method: a study including interphase effects

article-meta.aff: Composites Research Laboratory, Mechanical Engineering Department, Center of Excellence in Experimental Solid Mechanics and Dynamics, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: M.M. Shokrieh, Composites Research Laboratory, Mechanical Engineering Department, Center of Excellence in Experimental Solid Mechanics and Dynamics, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, Tehran 16846-13114, Iran Email: Shokrieh@iust.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In polymer composites, thermal residual stresses arise due to the mismatch of the thermal expansion coefficients of the fiber and matrix. Polymer composites generally consist of three phases: fiber, matrix, and the interphase. In this article, to study the effects of the interphase on residual stresses, a three-dimensional energy-based closed-form solution is developed. Residual stresses are assumed variable along longitudinal and radial directions, and two Airy stress functions are introduced. By considering the interphase region, in comparison with the perfect bonding conditions, thermal residual stresses decrease. The longitudinal residual stress distribution is sensitive to the interphase thickness. The maximum axial stress occurs at the fiber mid-length and decreases by increasing the interphase thickness. The maximum fiber–interphase and interphase–matrix interfacial shear stresses vary by increasing the interphase thickness, whereas their position is approximately unchanged. An increase in the interphase thickness leads to a decrease of the shear stress concentration factor near the fiber ends. For different magnitudes of bonding efficiency, the interfacial radial stresses are zero at the maximum fiber length. Although, the interphase region has a minor effect on the interfacial radial stresses, it has a significant effect on the maximum interfacial radial stresses at the fiber ends.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In general, composite materials achieve their structural integrity by being cured or processed at elevated temperatures under pressure and/or in vacuum. In curing process, micro-residual stresses are induced due to the difference in coefficient of thermal expansions of fiber and matrix. Consequently, residual stresses are inherently presented in almost all composites.1

Residual stresses may lead to the progress of matrix cracking, and may also have an adverse effect on the mechanical properties of the composites. A micromechanical analysis is needed to study the effects of thermal residual stresses.2 These stresses are often ignored or underestimated in both design and analytic modeling that can lead to incorrect interpretations of material characteristics and mechanical behavior of composites.1

Several micro-analytical methods have been presented by various authors to determine residual stresses in a single fiber–matrix composite.3–16 These methods include elasticity solution, finite element method, and cylinder theory. Based on the theory of elasticity, stresses are obtained from the displacement filed; so, using this method requires assuming higher order displacement field to obtain greater accuracy for the stresses.3 Using this method, the out-of-plane stress components cannot be obtained and the effects of some geometric characteristics such as fiber length are ignored.4 Several finite element models such as unit cell models of square and hexagonal arrays with different boundary conditions have been considered in previous publications.5–11 Results from the cylinder theory are obtained for generalized plane-strain conditions, which are not quite suitable for fibers of finite length such as those used in fiber pull-in and push-out tests.3

Consequently, both elasticity and cylinder theory methods do not yield a general closed-form solution for thermal stresses in a fiber–matrix composite. The energy method can be used, in order to compensate aforementioned shortcomings. This method does not have the limiting assumptions of the other methods. The energy method provides a direct approach to obtain the residual stresses, instead of using an indirect approach.

Papanicolaou et al.17 presented the concept of imperfect bonding using the boundary interphase in composite materials. The interphase region may arise during thermal treatment of the material, because of the constituent interaction. In this case, the composite may be considered as consisting of three-phase material. The thickness of the interphase region depends on bonding efficiency, which is the degree of adhesion between the fiber and matrix.17 Moreover, perfect bonding means that the interphase region does not exist and composites only includes two phases (i.e., the fiber and matrix).

In this article, effects of the interphase region on residual stress fields are investigated. For this purpose, a three-dimensional (3D) closed-form solution has been proposed which can be used for the prediction of micro-residual stresses in a single-fiber–interphase–matrix composite. The proposed solution is based on the energy method. First, two suitable Airy stress functions are assumed. Then, by applying the equilibrium equations and boundary conditions, the other stress components in the fiber, matrix, and the interphase are obtained in terms of the two assumed Airy stress functions. In the next step, using the stress–strain relations, all strain components for the three phases are calculated. Finally, the total strain energy is formulated and based on the minimum total complementary energy principle, the two unknown of Airy stress functions are found, and as a result, the full state of residual stress components is obtained.

sec.title: Problem statement
sec.p:
In this study, the representative volume element (RVE) is considered as a single fiber–matrix composite with the interphase between them. These three phases are modeled as concentric circular cylinders, as shown in Figure 1. Cylindrical coordinates (r,θ,z) are selected with the z-axis corresponding to the axis of the fiber. The radii of fiber, matrix, and interphase are Rf,Rm, and Ri, respectively. The boundaries are traction-free and the composite is subjected to a temperature decrease during the curing process. Figure 1.
The three-phase composite model.

Due to the mismatch of thermal and mechanical properties between the three phases, micro-residual stresses are formed in composite constituents. Due to the bigger coefficient of thermal expansion of matrix in comparison with the fiber, the matrix axial residual stress is tensile, whereas the fiber is under compression. These residual stresses increase the possibility of fiber–matrix shearing, matrix cracking, and even fiber local buckling when the composite is subjected to compressive external loads. So, the aim of this article is to determine the thermal residual stress fields, considering the effects of the interphase region.

sec.title: Assumptions
sec.p:
The following assumptions are considered for the problem:
The composite is a three-phase material including the fiber, matrix, and interphase. Thus, the bonding between the matrix and fiber is assumed to be imperfect.
The fiber is embedded uniformly in the polymer matrix.
All three phases, i.e., the fiber, matrix, and the interphase are homogeneous and linearly elastic.
The fiber, matrix, and interphase are modeled as isotropic materials.
At the origin, there is a radial plane of symmetry perpendicular to the fiber axis.
The problem is axi-symmetric.

sec.title: The Airy stress functions
sec.p: Many engineering problems have a degree of axial symmetry, for example circular rings, discs, or thick cylinders. The stresses in the present 3D problem can be described by proper Airy stress functions. These stress functions must satisfy not only the equilibrium conditions, but also the compatibility relationships. In a cylindrical coordinate system, the equilibrium equations are:18 (1) (2)
For an axi-symmetric problem, the stress components in terms of the Airy stress functions φ are given by: (3) (4) (5) (6) (7)
Here, because of the axi-symmetry, Airy stress functions can be assumed as:3,19 (8)

The subscripts j=f,m,i refer to the fiber, matrix, and interphase, respectively. Also, the functions fn(r) and gn(z) are functions of radial and axial coordinates, respectively. Thus, using Equations (3)–(6) the stresses in the three phases can be written as: (9) (10) (11) (12)

Due to the stress-free state of the boundary conditions and the stress continuity at the fiber–interphase and interphase–matrix interfaces along radial direction, the number of unknown functions fn(r) decreases. Also, the axial stresses in composite constituents are maximum at the plane of symmetry and zero at the ends of the composite. Thus, the functions f1(r), f2(r), and f3(r) can be written as an unknown constant A1.19 Consequently, with respect to Equation (11), the axial stresses in the fiber, matrix, and interphase are:3,19 (13) (14) (15)

On the other hand, the equilibrium equation in axial direction yields: (16) where Vf,Vm,andVi are the fiber, matrix, and interphase volume fractions, respectively. Substituting Equations (13)–(15) into Equation (16) gives: (17)

Equation (17) relates the three unknown functions g1(z),g2(z),g3(z) to each other. So, there are actually two unknown functions. Using the total complementary energy principle, these two functions will be determined and the third one will be found from Equation (17). So, the axial, shear, radial, and tangential stress components can be obtained in composite constituents.

sec.title: Phase 1
sec.p: The fiber. Equation (13) shows the axial stress in the fiber. Thus, with respect to the first equilibrium equation (Equation (1)), shear stress of the fiber is: (18)
Since the fiber Airy stress function is only a function of z, then Equations(3) and(4) can be written as: (19)
Substituting Equation(9) in the second equilibrium equation (Equation (2)) gives: (20)

sec.title: Phase 2
sec.p: The interphase. Equation(4) introduces the axial stress in the interphase. Using equilibrium equations yields: (21) (22)

sec.title: Phase 3
sec.p: The matrix. By considering Equations(6) and (17), the matrix axial stress is: (23)
The equilibrium equations give: (24) (25)
The procedure for determining of C1(z),C2(z), andC3(z) is described, in this article.

sec.title: Boundary and continuity conditions
sec.p: First, the radial stress at the outer surfaces of the matrix is zero:2 (26)
Second, the stresses must be continuous across the fiber–interphase and interphase–matrix interfaces:20 (27) (28)

Equations (26)–(28) lead to calculating the unknown functions C1(z),C2(z), andC3(z). Thus, (29) (30)
(31) (32)
(33) (34)

Third, due to symmetry, at the mid-length of the fiber the axial stresses in the fiber, interphase and matrix are maximum and the shear stresses are zero. Also the stress-free conditions give zero axial and shear stresses at the end of the fiber.3 Consequently, (35)

sec.title: Energy minimization
sec.p: Considering the section ‘Assumptions', the thermo-elastic stress–strain relations can be written as: (36) (37) (38) (39)
The superscript j denotes the fiber, matrix, and interphase. E,G, and ν are the modulus of elasticity, shear modulus, and Poisson's ratio, respectively.

The two constants A1,A2 and the two unknown functions g1(z),g2(z) will be obtained using the minimum total complementary energy principle. The total complementary energy is: (40) where U is the complementary strain energy and U* the complementary potential energy. Here, U*=0 because the composite is free of any external load. Thus, (41)

Now, by substituting functions C1(z),C2(z), andC3(z)of Equations (29)–(34) into Equations (20), (22), and (25), stresses in the fiber, matrix, and interphase of Equations (13), (14), (18), (20), and (21)–(25) and the stress–strain relations of Equations (36)–(39) into Equation (41), the total complementary energy can be obtained.
Integrating with respect to r and θ gives an integral function in terms of two constants A1,A2, two unknown functions g1(z),g2(z) and their derivatives. Thus, (42)
Using calculus of variations, the Euler–Lagrange equation is: (43)

Differentiating term by term in Equation(3) results in two coupled fourth-order ordinary differential equations with respect to g1(z),g2(z). Because of the complexity of the mathematics, the mathematical software, Maple 12 has been used. The solution of the two coupled differential equations includes eight unknown constants that will be determined by applying the eight boundary conditions in Equation (35).

The solutions have two undetermined constants A1,A2. Substituting the solutions obtained for g1(z),g2(z) and their derivatives into Equation(2) and then integrating with respect to z gives the total complementary energy in terms ofA1,A2. Thus, by applying the following equations, a system of linear algebraic equations will be obtained and the two unknown constantsA1,A2 will be determined: (44) (45)
The complete solution for Airy stress functions (φj)is now obtained. Substitution into equations (3)–(6) yields the thermal residual stress in the fiber, matrix, and interphase.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p:
In this section, the method is applied for glass fiber/epoxy resin composites (just as an example) with constituent properties given in Table 1.21,22 The obtained results are compared with the results for a perfect bonding condition, presented by Quek.3 For the fiber–matrix composite described in Table 1, the interphase thickness is reported to be variable (0.3, 0.4, or 0.7 µm), due to different surface treatments and unavoidable material imperfections.21where Lcr is the critical fiber length. When the length of the fiber is much greater than this critical value, the end effects can be neglected and the fiber may be considered to be continuous. So, this behavior introduces a long fiber composite. The critical fiber length is defined as:22 (46) where σfu and τb are the fiber ultimate strength and fiber–matrix bond strength, respectively. The temperature decrease is assumed to be 40°C. Table 1.
Typical properties of three phases1,21,22
Fiber Matrix Interphase
Young's modulus (GPa) 77 3.1 10.2
Poisson's ratio 0.25 0.34 0.28
Coefficient of thermal expansion (10-6/∘C) 4.8 70 20
Radius (μm) 6 8.5 6.3, 6.4, 6.7a
L=4Lcr
a
Obtained experimentally and reported in Matzenmiller and Gerlach.21

To provide a better insight, the results of the model are compared with the results of some other methods presented in the literature previously, as shown in Figures 2 and 3. As seen, the fiber and matrix axial stresses for the previous methods (i.e., the theory of elasticity and pressurized cylinder theory) are constant and valid just under perfect bonding condition as opposed to the presented method in which the axial stresses are variable along the fiber length axis and valid for both perfect and imperfect bonding conditions. Figure 2.
Fiber axial residual stress distribution. Figure 3.
Matrix axial residual stress distribution.

The axial residual stresses are symmetric about the mid-plane. Thus, these stresses are presented for half-length of the composite. Figures 2 and 3 compare the axial stress distribution in the fiber and matrix for different thicknesses of interphase region. As it is seen, increasing the thickness of the interphase region leads to decrease in the fiber and matrix axial stresses. The axial stress distribution is sensitive to the interphase thickness, whereas the results obtained based on perfect bonding by Quek3 ignore the effects of interphase region. Comparing with the perfect bonding results, a thickness of 0.7μm for the interphase leads to about 32% and 15% decrease in maximum value of fiber and matrix axial stresses, respectively.

The fiber axial stress is compressive, while the matrix has tensile axial stress. If the composite is subjected to a tensile load along the longitudinal direction, the fiber negative axial stresses can be beneficial. In contrast, in compressive load, these stresses can increase the possibility of some undesirable phenomena such as fiber–matrix shearing or fiber local buckling. Also, the matrix tensile residual stresses may result in many micro-cracks in the polymer matrix. The peak of axial stresses occurs at the mid-length of the fiber. The axial stress curves show a stress sharing between the three phases of composite according to Equation (16).

The fiber–interphase and interphase–matrix interfacial shear stresses, presented in Figures 4 and 5, are asymmetric about the mid-plane of the fiber length. They reach the maximum magnitudes in the vicinity of the fiber ends. So, there is a stress singularity near both the fiber ends. An increase in interphase thickness leads to decreasing the fiber–interphase and interphase–matrix interfacial shear stresses. For the interphase thickness equal to 0.7μm, the maximum interphase–matrix shear stress decreases about 42% in comparison with the perfect bonding condition. Figure 4.
Fiber–interphase interfacial shear stress distribution. Figure 5.
Interphase–matrix interfacial shear stress distribution.

Similar to the comparisons made for axial stress results, here interfacial radial stresses are analyzed based on the present and previous methods and the results are reflected in Figures 6 and 7. As seen, according to the present method, the symmetric interfacial radial stress distribution is approximately zero over the 70% of the fiber length, but has a considerable magnitude at the fiber ends. This can be attributed to the free-edge effect singularity addressed in Lessard et al.23 Although the thickness of interphase region has little effects on interfacial radial stress distribution, it has a significant effect on maximum interfacial radial stress at fiber ends. For instance the maximum interphase–matrix radial stress for the interphase thickness equal to 0.7μm, is 42% of the maximum value for perfect bonding condition. Figure 6.
Fiber–interphase interfacial radial stress distribution. Figure 7.
Interphase–matrix interfacial radial stress distribution.
The above-mentioned behavior can be compared with that of the previous works in Figures 6 and 7 in which the interfacial radial stresses remain constant along the fiber axis.

Table 2 shows the maximum interfacial radial stress for various interphase thicknesses based on the presented method. Table 2.
Maximum interfacial radial stresses at fiber ends for various interphase thicknesses
Interphase thickness (μm) 0 (perfect bonding) 0.3 0.4 0.7
Maximum fiber–interphase radial stress (MPa) 5.13 (maximum fiber–matrix radial stress) 4.79 4.66 4.14
Maximum interphase–matrix radial stress (MPa) 5.13 (maximum fiber–matrix radial stress) 3.67 3.26 2.21

Consequently, the interphase region has a significant role in thermal residual stress fields. The maximum magnitude of interfacial shear and radial micro-residual stresses dependent on interphase thickness. If the maximum shear stress exceeds the interfacial shear strength, fiber debonding may occur, especially when the composite is loaded externally. Also, maximum magnitudes of the radial stresses at the ends of the fiber can result in a failure in fiber–interphase and interphase–matrix interfaces, when the composite is subjected to tensile external loads.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, based on the energy method, a closed-form solution for the prediction of thermal residual stresses in fibrous composites is obtained which considers the interphase region effects. RVE is considered as a three-phase composite, which includes the fiber and matrix, as well as the interphase between them. The residual stresses are assumed variable along the longitudinal and radial directions, choosing suitable Airy stress functions. Based on the minimum total complementary energy principle approach, unknown Airy stress functions and thus micro-residual stress fields are obtained.

The present solution takes into account more precious assumptions in comparison with the previous analytical solutions, because of some reasons. First, previous solutions (the generalized plane–strain theory and the theory of elasticity) are just suitable for perfect bonding conditions (which corresponds to a two-phase composites, made of fiber and matrix), whereas the present solution considers imperfect adhesion between the fiber and matrix (a three-phase composite including fiber and matrix as well as interphase between them). Second, previous methods are not able to give the residual shear stress. Besides using these methods, the out-of-plane stress components cannot be obtained and the effects of some geometric characteristics such as fiber length are ignored, while the presented method gives a full set of residual stress components. Third, while based on the two previous solutions, the residual stresses are usually assumed to be independent of the longitudinal coordinate, the present solution assumes that these stresses vary along the fiber length and are functions of longitudinal coordinate. Consequently, the present method gives a better knowledge about the behavior of residual stress distribution along the fiber length. Fourth; previous methods do not satisfy some boundary conditions, especially at the ends of the fiber, while the present method satisfies all boundary conditions. For example, from the two previous methods, the fiber, interphase, and matrix axial stresses are not zero at the ends of the fiber, at which stress-free conditions give zero axial and shear stresses. Fifth, the present solution takes into account the edge effect singularity in contrast with the two previous ones.

In comparison with the perfect bonding conditions, considering the interphase leads to considerable variations in the axial residual stress distribution for the three phases. For both perfect and imperfect bonding conditions, the maximum axial stress occurs at the fiber mid-length, but their magnitudes mainly decrease if the interphase thickness increases.

Depending upon the interphase thickness, a fiber–interphase and interphase–matrix interfacial shear stress concentration appears at the vicinity of both fiber ends. An increase in the interphase thickness leads to decrease in the shear stress concentration factor. Thus, for a narrow interphase region, fiber debonding occurs if these shear stresses exceed the interfacial shear strength. Also if the bonding efficiency decreases (which leads to an increase in interphase thickness) the position of the maximum interfacial shear stress gradually moves to the fiber ends.

The interfacial radial stress distribution is not sensitive to the interphase characteristics. Considering the perfect bonding condition in comparison with the imperfect bonding case leads to overestimating the micro-residual stresses. Narrow interphase region composites have more thermal residual stresses. Thus, one may say that in order to decrease the curing stresses, it is benefit to increase the interphase thickness. However, increasing the interphase thickness decreases the bonding efficiency that means the composite has a lower strength if it is subjected to external loads. Consequently, although increasing the interphase thickness results in lower thermal residual stresses, there is an optimum value for interphase thickness when both thermal residual stresses and external loads exist.

It should be noted that the mechanical and thermal properties of the interphase affect the thermal residual stress fields. Investigation of effective parameters on thermal residual stresses necessitates variation of interphase properties. Thermal and mechanical properties of interphase are different from fiber and matrix properties, but depend on their properties. This subject is currently being studied in a complementary research work by the present authors.
